before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"8d5he","text":"Take all the reagencies out of a freezer and let them temperate to room temperature. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"dhqov","text":"This protocol is dedicated to evaluation of 16S rRNA bacteria gene copy number using Droplet Digital PCR technology (ddPCR) from Bio-Rad company. This is the up-to-date modification and improvement of clasical probe based qPCR assay. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":85,"length":38}],"data":{}},{"key":"dp05l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aac8u","text":"For the assay we are using universal 16S Bacteria primers and probe:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4c7pj","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2fvlt","text":"BAC338F      ACT CCT ACG GGA GGC AG , target E.coli :  338-354, Yu et al. (2005), B\u0026B","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":45,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqlse","text":"BAC516P*    TGC CAG CAG CCG CGG TAA TA, target E.coli :  516-536, '","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":47,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6h0c1","text":"BAC805R      GAC TAC CAG GGT ATC TAA TC , target E.coli :  785-805, '","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":49,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bpdm2","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dmegi","text":"* Probe must be dual-labelled either with 5’-6-FAM, 3’-BHQ1 or any other valid combination.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qchb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bq7q1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cf0qa","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"4vcdm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"A1B58FD074D811EA9D8A11E1CA31FA49","url":"https://www.bio-rad.com/en-cz/applications-technologies/droplet-digital-pcr-ddpcr-technology?ID=MDV31M4VY"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1bsub","text":"What is the difference between clasical qPCR and ddPCR target gene quantification? ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7rhob","text":"Among the bigest advantages of the ddPCR technique belong its high sensitivity (up to one molecule of target gene presented in input DNA) and robustness to enzyme inhibitors. Moreover, because it is an absolute quantification technique there is NO need of any internal standard for evaluation.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8umu5","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

groups.title: SoWa RI Anaerobic and Molecular Microbiology (public)

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"b4ill","text":"The crucial steps that can influence the final results a lot are precise pipetting, mixing and dilutions!","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":65,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dh4ql","text":"Keep in mind that ddPCR technigue do not posses as wide dynamic concentration range as qPCR does. You can easily \"overload\" the reaction with too much template DNA putting in. In that case you will see only positive droplets at the end and no negatives and system will not be able to calculate copy number from that. As a consequence, you usually have to dilute your template DNA more than for qPCR experiments. Ideally fit inside the range of 101 - 104 coppies of target gene. That is why we usually test several dilutions of few samples before to see \"where we are\".","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":446,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":452,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"904ek","text":"One have to also keep in mind that using ddPCR technology you must work within the format of eight. If you do not fulfil all the wells in a cartridge you still have to put the reagencies inside the empty wells as well. So, think economically before you start.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8n7ed","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6994i","text":"Set up the treshold just above negative control sample in order to distinguish positive (containing PCR products) from negative (do not contain PCR product) droplets.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"10rou","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9t8nt","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"0mhqz","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5tcf4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bv4rc","text":"Quanta software will automaticaly calculate copy number of target gene for each sample by Poisson distribution algorithm. {"blocks":[{"key":"3061g","text":"Set up the QuntaSoft experiment as follows:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ea4eh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7120l","text":"Exp. type:        Absolute quantification (ABS)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eqpgq","text":"Supermix:       ddPCR Supermix for Probe","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"co3r2","text":"Target1:          Ch1 (for FAM labeled probes)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3h979","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b11bq","text":"Define the position of ech sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d2k0c","text":"Start measurement.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d32i8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5p597","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"balt8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bf3qe","text":"After it finishes go over the results and see how many droplets were executed for each sample. We usually have got 18.000 - 20.000 droplets analyzed per sample.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dchgc","text":" ","type":"atomic"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aahcd","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"2E90733E344811EEAFD10A58A9FEAC02","height":236,"is_video":false,"legend":"{\"blocks\":[{\"key\":\"2fq5k\",\"text\":\"An example of total droplet counts, including positives and negatives together, for several environmental samples.\",\"type\":\"unstyled\",\"depth\":0,\"inlineStyleRanges\":[],\"entityRanges\":[],\"data\":{}}],\"entityMap\":{}}","mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/public/1699dc345bd1e79cfd8cb53f5b62703b3208b8c6ce5a9fb99440ba631b9884a4/b9wyi2aw.png","source":"https://content.protocols.io/public/1699dc345bd1e79cfd8cb53f5b62703b3208b8c6ce5a9fb99440ba631b9884a4/b9wxi2aw.png","type":1,"width":550},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"image"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3n51b","text":"Export .csv file with concentrations (copies/ul) that are posessing you the number of copies in 1ul of reaction. To obtain number of copies in 1ul of your input DNA you have to recalculate:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5s7c9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"etrs","text":"no. of copies in 1ul of input DNA = (concentration value x 22)/ volume of DNA ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
